tn.ref: David counted the soldiers who were with him and appointed
tn.text: David did not count all of the people himself, rather other men counted them. AT: "David commanded for the soldiers who were with him to be counted and he appointed" or "David arranged the soldiers who were with him and appointed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
A captain is a person who is in authority over a group of soldiers.
third ... another third** - "one-third of the army ... another third of the army." A "third" is one part out of three equal parts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_fraction]])
Translate these mens' names the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:02:18|2:18]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Translate this man's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:19|15:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to a person from Gath, which is a Philistine city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: I will certainly go out with you myself, too
tn.text: This means that he will go out with them to battle. This can be stated clearly. AT: "I myself will go with you to battle" (UDB) or "I personally will go with you into battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "half" refers to one out of two equal parts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: you are worth ten thousand of us
tn.text: This means that the enemy army considering killing David of greater worth than killing 10,000 of the other men. The number 10,000 here is an exaggeration used to emphasize a very great number of people. AT: "they would rather kill you than to kill 10,000 of us" or "killing you is worth more to them than killing a great number of us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"10,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: that you be ready to help us from the city
tn.text: David could help them from the city by advising them and sending men to help them. This can be stated clearly. AT: "that you stay here in the city and send help to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Translate this man's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:02:18|2:18]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Translate this man's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:19|15:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Deal gently for my sake with the young man, with Absalom
tn.text: "For my sake, do not harm the young man, Absalom." The phrase "Deal gently" means to be kind to someone and not to harm them.
"my well-being" or "my account"

tn.ref: went out into the countryside against Israel
tn.text: This means that they went out and fought against them in battle. AT: "went out into the countryside and fought against Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "Israel" refers to their soldiers, not all of the Israelites. AT: "against the Israelite soldiers" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: The army of Israel was defeated there before the soldiers of David
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "There the soldiers of David defeated the army of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
an event where many people are brutally killed
"20,000 men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: more men were consumed by the forest than by the sword
tn.text: Here "the forest" is described as if it were alive and could act. "The sword" refers to David's soldiers who fought with swords. AT: "dangerous things in the forest killed more men than David's soldiers killed with their swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Absalom happened to meet some of David's soldiers
tn.text: This is an event that happened during the battle. This can be stated clearly. AT: "During the battle, Absalom happened to meet some of David's soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: his head was caught up in the tree branches
tn.text: Absalom had long hair that got caught in the tree branches. AT: "his hair was caught in the tree branches" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
hanging or swinging loosely

tn.ref: between the ground and the sky
tn.text: "in the air" (UDB)
Here this word is used to draw a person's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Why did you not strike him down to the ground?
tn.text: This rhetorical question means that he should have killed him. This question can be written as a statement. The phrase "strike down" means to kill. AT: "You should have struck him down to the ground!" or "You should have killed him immediately!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This can be written in modern units. AT: "ten silver coins" or "110 grams of silver" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
This is a special belt that shows people that someone is a great soldier and should be honored.

"1,000 silver shekels." This can be stated in modern units. AT: "1,000 silver coins" or "11 kilograms of silver" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: would not have reached out my hand against the king's son
tn.text: The phrase "reached out my hand" means to attack. AT: "would not have attacked the king's son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "touching" refers to "harming." AT: "No none must harm" or "Do not harm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The word "falsehood" can be expressed with a verb phrase. Also, this refers to disobeying the king's command. This can be stated clearly. AT: "doing something that is wrong" or "by disobeying the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: there is nothing hidden from the king
tn.text: Here the man speaks about how the king knows about almost everything that happens as if everything were a physical object he knew the location of. AT: "there is nothing that the king does not know" or "the king hears about everything that happens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will not wait for you
tn.text: Joab meant that he should not continue talking to the man. AT: "I will not waste anymore time talking to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here Absalom's heart refers to his chest or upper body. AT: "chest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This refers to both the armor he would wear to protect himself and to his weapons. AT: "armor and weapons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Then Joab blew the trumpet, and the army returned from pursuing Israel, for Joab held back the army
tn.text: This describes what Joab commanded by blowing the trumpet. AT: "Then Joab blew the trumpet to call back the army, and the army returned from pursuing Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "Israel" refers to the Israelite army. AT: "returned from pursuing the Israelite army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They took Absalom and threw him
tn.text: "They took Absalom's body and threw it"

tn.ref: they buried his body under a very large pile of stones
tn.text: After putting his body in the pit they covered it with a pile of stones. This can be stated more clearly. AT: "they covered his body with a huge pile of stones" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "all Israel" refers to the Israelite soldiers. The word "fled" means "ran away." AT: "while all the Israelite soldiers ran away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: to carry along the memory of my name
tn.text: Absalom uses the phrase "my name" to refer to himself and his family line. AT: "to carry on my family name, by which people would remember me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: so it is called Absalom's Monument to this very day
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "so people called it Absalom's Monument from that day on" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to the present time when this book of the Bible was written.
Translate this man's name the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:15:27|15:27]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: run to the king with the good news
tn.text: Here Ahimaaz speaks of running to go and tell the king the good news as if the good news were a object that he were carrying. AT: "run to tell the king the good news" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "hand" refers to control. AT: "the control of his enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"the one who tells the news"
This refers to not bearing the news to the king. AT: "you will not tell the news to the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: tell the king what you have seen
tn.text: Joab is telling him to go and tell the king about the news of the battle.
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline and the beginning of a new part of the story.
Here the watchman looking to see something is spoken of as if he lifted up his eyes. AT: "and looked out beyond the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: there is news in his mouth
tn.text: Here the king speaks of the man having a message as if the news were an object sitting in his mouth. AT: "he has news to tell us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I think the running of the man in front is like the running of Ahimaaz son of Zadok
tn.text: The watchman compares the way the man ran to the way Ahimaaz runs to suggest that it may be him. AT: "I think the man running in front is Ahimaaz son Zadok, because he runs like Ahimaaz" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: He bowed himself before the king with his face to the ground
tn.text: He did this to honor the king. AT: "He bowed himself before the king with his face to the ground to honor the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"Praise Yahweh." Here "bless" means to praise.

tn.ref: the men who lifted up their hand against my master the king
tn.text: Here Ahimaaz speaks of the men opposing the king as if they were were raising their hands before him. AT: "the men who opposed and fought against my master the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This means that people were acting as though things were not right.
"Move out of the way" or "Stand aside" (UDB)
This means to oppose. AT: "opposed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: The enemies of my master the king, ... should be as that young man is
tn.text: The Cushite uses a comparison as a polite way to tell the king that Absalom is dead. This can be stated more directly. AT: "I would like all your enemies ... to die the way that young man died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"upset"
